questions.stem: A behavior therapist is treating a client with a specific phobia of spiders. The therapist teaches the client progressive muscle relaxation, constructs a graded anxiety hierarchy using SUDs ratings, and then has the client imagine each scene while maintaining relaxation. This treatment is best described as:

options.text: Flooding
Systematic desensitization
Implosive therapy
Exposure and response prevention

questions.explanation: Systematic desensitization, developed by Wolpe, involves three steps: (1) relaxation training (PMR), (2) construction of an anxiety hierarchy using SUDs, and (3) pairing relaxation with progressive imaginal exposure to hierarchy items. It is based on reciprocal inhibition -- anxiety and relaxation are incompatible responses. Flooding involves intense exposure without relaxation. Implosive therapy (Stampfl) involves imaginal flooding with psychodynamic themes. ERP is specifically for OCD.

questions.stem: A client with OCD performs hand-washing rituals for hours daily after touching doorknobs. The therapist instructs the client to touch multiple doorknobs (without gloves) and then refrain from washing for a prolonged period while the anxiety naturally decreases. This treatment is:

options.text: Systematic desensitization
Aversion therapy
Exposure and response prevention (ERP)
Covert sensitization

questions.explanation: ERP is the gold standard treatment for OCD. It combines exposure (contact with the obsession-triggering stimulus -- doorknobs) with response prevention (refraining from the compulsive ritual -- hand-washing). Both components are necessary: exposure activates the anxiety, and response prevention prevents the compulsion from providing negative reinforcement, allowing the anxiety to habituate and the obsession-compulsion cycle to break.

questions.stem: A therapist terminates a flooding session early because the client becomes too distressed. According to learning theory, the most likely outcome of this premature termination is:

options.text: Extinction of the conditioned fear response
Sensitization, with increased fear of the stimulus
Reciprocal inhibition of the anxiety response
Spontaneous recovery of the original unconditioned response

questions.explanation: If a flooding session is terminated before habituation occurs, the client escapes at peak anxiety. This escape is negatively reinforced (the aversive anxiety is removed), which strengthens the avoidance behavior and can lead to sensitization -- an actual increase in fear. This is why flooding sessions must be long enough (typically 60-90 minutes) for anxiety to habituate. Premature escape is one of the primary risks of flooding.

questions.stem: In a token economy on a psychiatric inpatient unit, patients earn points for attending group therapy and completing hygiene routines, which they exchange for TV time and phone calls. The tokens in this system function as:

options.text: Primary reinforcers
Unconditioned reinforcers
Generalized conditioned reinforcers
Negative reinforcers

questions.explanation: Tokens are generalized conditioned (secondary) reinforcers because they acquire reinforcing value through association with multiple backup reinforcers (TV time, phone calls, etc.). They are 'generalized' because they can be exchanged for a variety of backup reinforcers, similar to how money functions in everyday life. Primary/unconditioned reinforcers satisfy biological needs (food, water). Negative reinforcers involve removal of aversive stimuli.

questions.stem: A parent tells a child, 'You can play video games after you finish your homework.' This application of making a high-probability behavior contingent upon completion of a low-probability behavior is known as:

options.text: Negative reinforcement
The Premack Principle
Differential reinforcement of alternative behavior
Response cost

questions.explanation: The Premack Principle (also called 'Grandma's Rule') states that a high-probability behavior (video games) can reinforce a low-probability behavior (homework) when access to the preferred activity is made contingent on completing the less preferred activity. This is not negative reinforcement (no aversive stimulus is being removed) or DRA (no specific alternative to a problem behavior is being reinforced). Response cost involves removing earned reinforcers.

questions.stem: Select all that apply. Which of the following are strategies identified by Stokes and Baer (1977) for promoting generalization of behavior change?

options.text: Train sufficient exemplars across multiple settings and people
Use natural reinforcers present in the environment
Program common stimuli between training and natural settings
Maintain continuous reinforcement schedules indefinitely
Restrict all training to a single controlled setting

questions.explanation: Stokes and Baer (1977) identified strategies including: training sufficient exemplars (across settings, people, stimuli), using natural reinforcers, programming common stimuli, training loosely (varying conditions), and using indiscriminable contingencies (shifting to intermittent reinforcement). Maintaining continuous reinforcement and restricting training to one setting would actually impair generalization. The partial reinforcement extinction effect (PREE) means intermittent schedules produce more durable behavior.

questions.stem: Select all that apply. According to the inhibitory learning model of exposure therapy (Craske et al., 2014), which of the following strategies maximize the effectiveness of exposure?

options.text: Designing exposures to maximally violate the client's specific threat expectancy
Conducting exposure across varied stimuli, contexts, and intensities
Gradually removing safety behaviors that prevent full inhibitory learning
Waiting for SUDs to reach zero within each session before progressing
Ensuring the client experiences no anxiety during exposure sessions

questions.explanation: The inhibitory learning model proposes that exposure creates a new, competing association rather than erasing the original fear. Key strategies: expectancy violation (disconfirming threat predictions), variability (varied stimuli/contexts), removal of safety signals, and deepened extinction. Unlike the habituation model, within-session fear reduction (SUDs reaching zero) is neither necessary nor sufficient. Anxiety during exposure is expected and not problematic under this model.

questions.stem: Select all that apply. Which of the following are identified as the four primary functions of behavior in a functional behavior assessment (FBA)?

options.text: Attention (social reinforcement)
Escape/avoidance of aversive demands
Access to tangible items or activities
Automatic/sensory reinforcement
Expression of unconscious conflict

questions.explanation: The four functions of behavior in FBA are: (1) attention (behavior maintained by social attention -- positive reinforcement), (2) escape/avoidance (behavior removes aversive demands -- negative reinforcement), (3) access to tangibles (behavior produces preferred items/activities -- positive reinforcement), and (4) automatic/sensory (behavior produces its own sensory reinforcement independent of social consequences). 'Expression of unconscious conflict' is a psychoanalytic concept, not a behavioral function.

questions.stem: Select all that apply. Which of the following correctly describe the extinction burst phenomenon?

options.text: A temporary increase in frequency, intensity, or variability of behavior when reinforcement is first withheld
It occurs because the organism initially 'tries harder' when a previously effective behavior stops producing reinforcement
If the caregiver gives in during the burst, they reinforce a more intense version of the behavior
It indicates that extinction is failing and the intervention should be abandoned
It only occurs with behaviors maintained on continuous reinforcement schedules

questions.explanation: An extinction burst is a temporary escalation when reinforcement is first withheld. The organism 'tries harder' before the behavior decreases. If reinforcement is provided during the burst, the more intense behavior is reinforced through intermittent reinforcement, making it more resistant to future extinction. The burst is a normal part of extinction, not a sign of failure. Extinction bursts can occur with any reinforcement history, though behaviors on intermittent schedules may show more pronounced and prolonged bursts.

questions.stem: Select all that apply. Which of the following are types of differential reinforcement procedures used to decrease problem behavior without punishment?

options.text: DRO -- reinforcing the absence of the target behavior for a specified interval
DRA -- reinforcing a specific desirable alternative behavior
DRI -- reinforcing a behavior physically incompatible with the problem behavior
DRL -- reinforcing the behavior only when it occurs at or below a specified rate
DRE -- reinforcing emotional expression during the problem behavior

questions.explanation: The four differential reinforcement procedures are: DRO (reinforcing absence of behavior for a time interval), DRA (reinforcing a specific desirable alternative), DRI (reinforcing a physically incompatible behavior), and DRL (reinforcing low rates of the behavior). DRE is not a recognized differential reinforcement procedure. All four procedures reduce problem behavior without using punishment by selectively reinforcing desired behavior patterns.

questions.stem: Match each behavioral treatment to the principle or mechanism it is primarily based upon.

columns.text: Extinction through prolonged exposure and habituation

questions.explanation: Systematic desensitization is based on reciprocal inhibition (Wolpe) -- pairing relaxation with anxiety-provoking stimuli to countercondition the fear. Flooding works through extinction via prolonged exposure and habituation. Aversion therapy uses classical conditioning to pair a desired stimulus with an aversive UCS. Token economies use operant reinforcement with tokens as generalized conditioned reinforcers.

questions.stem: Match each operant consequence to the correct definition.

rows.text: A child receives praise after cleaning their room, and room-cleaning increases.
A headache goes away after taking aspirin, and aspirin-taking increases.
A student loses recess privileges after misbehaving, and misbehavior decreases.
A child receives a scolding after hitting, and hitting decreases.

questions.explanation: Row 1: positive reinforcement -- adding praise (desirable) increases behavior. Row 2: negative reinforcement -- removing headache (aversive) increases aspirin-taking. Row 3: negative punishment -- removing recess (desirable) decreases misbehavior. Row 4: positive punishment -- adding scolding (aversive) decreases hitting. 'Positive/negative' = adding/removing; reinforcement increases behavior, punishment decreases it.

questions.stem: For each exposure-based treatment, select ALL characteristics that correctly apply.

columns.text: Involves intense, prolonged exposure at full intensity
Incorporates psychodynamic themes into imaginal scenes
Specifically prevents compulsive rituals following exposure

questions.explanation: Systematic desensitization uses relaxation (reciprocal inhibition). Flooding involves intense, prolonged exposure (in vivo or imaginal). Implosive therapy (Stampfl) involves intense imaginal exposure AND incorporates psychodynamic themes. ERP involves prolonged exposure to obsession triggers AND specifically prevents compulsive rituals. Note that ERP is the only approach that includes ritual prevention as a core component.

questions.stem: For each chaining method, select ALL characteristics that correctly describe it.

columns.text: Teaches the first step first; therapist assists with remaining steps
Teaches the last step first; therapist completes all preceding steps
Teaches all steps simultaneously with prompts at each step
Each step serves as an SD for the next and a reinforcer for the previous

questions.explanation: Forward chaining: teach step 1 first, assist with the rest. Backward chaining: teach the last step first, the therapist does all preceding steps. Total task presentation: teach all steps at once with prompts. All chaining methods share the property that each step functions as a discriminative stimulus (SD) for the next behavior and as a conditioned reinforcer for the preceding behavior.

questions.stem: Systematic desensitization was developed by {{blank1}} and is based on the principle of {{blank2}}. The three steps are: first, the client learns {{blank3}}; second, a graded {{blank4}} is constructed using SUDs ratings from 0 to 100.

Victor Meyer

reciprocal inhibition

progressive muscle relaxation

questions.explanation: Systematic desensitization was developed by Joseph Wolpe (not Stampfl, who developed implosive therapy, or Meyer, who developed ERP). It is based on reciprocal inhibition -- the idea that relaxation inhibits anxiety. Step 1: progressive muscle relaxation (originally developed by Jacobson). Step 2: construction of a graded anxiety hierarchy with SUDs ratings. Step 3: pairing relaxation with hierarchy items from lowest to highest.

questions.stem: In operant conditioning, behaviors maintained on {{blank1}} reinforcement schedules extinguish more quickly than those on intermittent schedules, a phenomenon known as the {{blank2}}. When reinforcement is withheld, a temporary increase in behavior frequency called an {{blank3}} typically occurs. After extinction, the behavior may temporarily reappear following a rest period, which is called {{blank4}}.

options.text: continuous (CRF)
variable ratio
fixed interval
variable interval
habituation effect
partial reinforcement extinction effect (PREE)
schedules of reinforcement principle
generalization gradient
spontaneous recovery
response generalization
extinction burst
behavioral contrast
stimulus generalization
spontaneous recovery
reconditioning
disinhibition

questions.explanation: Continuous reinforcement (CRF) leads to faster extinction than intermittent schedules, known as the partial reinforcement extinction effect (PREE). When reinforcement is withheld, an extinction burst (temporary increase in behavior) occurs. After extinction, spontaneous recovery may occur -- the behavior temporarily reappears after a rest period. Continued non-reinforcement leads to re-extinction.

questions.stem: A 7-year-old child in a classroom frequently throws tantrums including screaming and throwing objects. A functional behavior assessment reveals that the tantrums consistently occur when the teacher gives work assignments and that the teacher typically sends the child to the hallway following outbursts, after which the child calms down.

options.text: The tantrum behavior is negatively reinforced by escape from academic demands
Sending the child to the hallway removes the aversive stimulus (the assignment), strengthening the tantrum
The behavior is maintained by automatic/sensory reinforcement
The behavior reflects an unresolved attachment disruption requiring psychodynamic exploration
Escape-maintained behavior pattern reinforced by removal of academic demands following tantrums
Attention-maintained behavior reinforced by teacher social interaction during tantrums
Oppositional defiant disorder requiring pharmacological intervention
Escape extinction (not allowing the child to avoid the task) combined with teaching appropriate break-requesting
DRA: reinforcing the child for using appropriate language to request help or a break
Planned ignoring (extinction of attention) during tantrums
Increasing the difficulty of work assignments to build frustration tolerance

questions.explanation: The FBA reveals escape-maintained behavior: tantrums occur when demands are presented (antecedent) and are followed by removal from the work environment (consequence = negative reinforcement). The teacher inadvertently reinforces tantrums by sending the child to the hallway. Interventions: escape extinction (the child must complete the work even after a tantrum) and DRA (teaching and reinforcing appropriate alternatives like asking for help or a break). Planned ignoring would be appropriate for attention-maintained behavior, not escape-maintained behavior.

questions.stem: A 35-year-old woman with major depressive disorder reports that she stopped attending her weekly book club, quit exercising, and spends most evenings watching television alone. She says, 'I don't feel like doing anything. Nothing sounds enjoyable anymore. I just don't have the energy or motivation.'

options.text: Behavioral withdrawal reducing contact with sources of positive reinforcement
Avoidance cycle: low mood leads to inactivity, which reduces reinforcement, worsening depression
Excessive positive reinforcement from television maintaining the avoidance behavior
Irrational demands that activities must be immediately pleasurable
Depression maintained by avoidance and reduced access to positive reinforcement, consistent with the behavioral model of depression
Agoraphobia with avoidance of public situations
Social anxiety disorder with fear of negative evaluation
Activity scheduling to systematically increase engagement with potentially reinforcing activities
Graded task assignment to break overwhelming activities into manageable steps
Flooding to force prolonged exposure to social situations
Aversion therapy to reduce television watching

questions.explanation: The client shows the classic behavioral model of depression: withdrawal from activities reduces contact with positive reinforcement, which worsens mood, leading to further withdrawal (an avoidance cycle). Behavioral activation targets this cycle directly. Activity scheduling systematically re-engages the client with reinforcing activities regardless of initial motivation. Graded task assignment breaks overwhelming tasks into manageable steps to build mastery. The goal is to increase reinforcement contact, not to use flooding or aversion.

questions.stem: Highlight ALL statements that are accurate regarding behavioral treatment principles and techniques.
questions.passage: In systematic desensitization, [the client is exposed to the most anxiety-provoking stimulus first, without any relaxation, and must remain until anxiety subsides]. Exposure and Response Prevention is [the gold standard behavioral treatment for OCD, combining exposure to triggers with prevention of compulsive rituals]. Implosive therapy, developed by Stampfl, [is distinguished from standard flooding by its incorporation of psychodynamic themes into imaginal exposure scenes]. In the inhibitory learning model, [the key mechanism of exposure is expectancy violation rather than within-session habituation]. Covert sensitization was developed by [Wolpe as a form of in vivo aversion therapy using physical stimuli]. Regarding biofeedback, [EMG biofeedback of the frontalis muscle is a common application for tension headaches].

highlightableSegments.text: the client is exposed to the most anxiety-provoking stimulus first, without any relaxation, and must remain until anxiety subsides
the gold standard behavioral treatment for OCD, combining exposure to triggers with prevention of compulsive rituals
is distinguished from standard flooding by its incorporation of psychodynamic themes into imaginal exposure scenes
the key mechanism of exposure is expectancy violation rather than within-session habituation
Wolpe as a form of in vivo aversion therapy using physical stimuli
EMG biofeedback of the frontalis muscle is a common application for tension headaches

questions.explanation: Segments 2, 3, 4, and 6 are accurate. Segment 1 describes flooding, not systematic desensitization (which uses gradual exposure paired with relaxation). Segment 5 is wrong: covert sensitization was developed by Cautela (not Wolpe) and is a purely imaginal technique (not in vivo) using imagined aversive consequences.

questions.stem: Highlight ALL statements that contain accurate information about operant conditioning procedures.
questions.passage: Time-out from positive reinforcement is [a form of negative punishment that decreases behavior by temporarily removing access to reinforcement]. The partial reinforcement extinction effect (PREE) indicates that [behaviors maintained on continuous reinforcement schedules are more resistant to extinction than those on intermittent schedules]. Overcorrection involves two components: [restitutional overcorrection, which requires restoring the environment, and positive practice overcorrection, which requires repeatedly practicing the correct behavior]. In a quid pro quo contract, [each partner's behavior change is reinforced independently of the other's behavior]. Regarding shaping, [successive approximations of the target behavior are reinforced, gradually requiring closer approximations before delivering reinforcement]. Response cost is [a form of positive punishment that involves adding an aversive stimulus contingent on undesired behavior].

highlightableSegments.text: a form of negative punishment that decreases behavior by temporarily removing access to reinforcement
behaviors maintained on continuous reinforcement schedules are more resistant to extinction than those on intermittent schedules
restitutional overcorrection, which requires restoring the environment, and positive practice overcorrection, which requires repeatedly practicing the correct behavior
each partner's behavior change is reinforced independently of the other's behavior
successive approximations of the target behavior are reinforced, gradually requiring closer approximations before delivering reinforcement
a form of positive punishment that involves adding an aversive stimulus contingent on undesired behavior

questions.explanation: Segments 1, 3, and 5 are accurate. Segment 2 reverses the PREE: continuously reinforced behaviors extinguish MORE quickly; intermittently reinforced behaviors are MORE resistant to extinction. Segment 4 describes a good faith contract, not a quid pro quo contract (quid pro quo links one partner's change to the other's). Segment 6 is wrong: response cost is negative punishment (removing earned reinforcers), not positive punishment.

questions.stem: Arrange the three steps of Wolpe's systematic desensitization in the correct order of implementation.

items.text: The client learns progressive muscle relaxation (PMR), systematically tensing and releasing muscle groups
The client and therapist construct a graded anxiety hierarchy using SUDs ratings (0-100)
Beginning with the lowest item, the client imagines each scene while maintaining relaxation
The client progresses to the next hierarchy level only when anxiety no longer arises at the current level
If anxiety emerges, the client returns to relaxation before re-attempting the item
Treatment continues until the client can imagine the highest hierarchy item without anxiety

questions.explanation: Systematic desensitization proceeds in order: (1) learn PMR, (2) construct the graded hierarchy, (3) begin pairing relaxation with the lowest item, (4) progress only when the current level is mastered, (5) return to relaxation if anxiety emerges, (6) continue until the highest item is handled without anxiety. The gradual, stepwise progression paired with relaxation is what distinguishes systematic desensitization from flooding.

questions.stem: Arrange the eight phases of EMDR in the correct sequential order as described by Shapiro.

items.text: History taking and treatment planning
Preparation -- teaching coping skills and establishing safety
Assessment -- identifying target memory, negative cognition, positive cognition, and baseline SUDs
Desensitization -- focusing on the traumatic memory during bilateral stimulation
Installation -- strengthening the desired positive cognition
Body scan -- checking for residual physical tension related to the target memory

questions.explanation: EMDR's eight phases in order: (1) History/treatment planning, (2) Preparation (coping skills, safety), (3) Assessment (target memory, negative/positive cognitions, baseline SUDs), (4) Desensitization (bilateral stimulation while focusing on trauma), (5) Installation (strengthening positive cognition), (6) Body scan (checking for residual tension), followed by (7) Closure (returning to equilibrium) and (8) Reevaluation (assessing effects at next session).

questions.stem: A researcher compares systematic desensitization with flooding for the treatment of specific phobia (fear of heights). Both groups rate their anxiety on a SUDs scale (0-100) at five time points during the first treatment session.
questions.question: What do these within-session anxiety patterns reveal about the different mechanisms of these two treatments?

options.text: Both treatments produce identical anxiety reduction patterns
Systematic desensitization maintains low anxiety through reciprocal inhibition, while flooding produces initial spike followed by habituation
Flooding is ineffective because anxiety increases during the session
Systematic desensitization produces more anxiety than flooding

questions.explanation: Systematic desensitization starts with low-anxiety items and maintains manageable anxiety through reciprocal inhibition (relaxation), so SUDs remain low and gradually decrease (25 to 12). Flooding immediately exposes the client to intense stimuli, producing a sharp anxiety spike (85-90) followed by within-session habituation as the autonomic nervous system cannot maintain peak arousal indefinitely (down to 35). Both are effective but via different mechanisms: counterconditioning vs. extinction through habituation.

questions.stem: A contingency management program for cocaine dependence tracks the number of drug-negative urine samples per month for a treatment group (receiving escalating voucher reinforcement) and a control group (standard treatment without vouchers).
questions.question: What do these data demonstrate about the effectiveness of contingency management for substance use?

options.text: Both groups show equivalent improvement in abstinence rates over time
The voucher-based CM group shows substantially greater and faster increases in drug-negative samples, with the escalating reinforcement producing accelerating gains
The standard treatment group shows faster initial improvement
Contingency management produces no meaningful difference from standard treatment

questions.explanation: The voucher-based CM group shows rapid, substantial increases in clean samples (2 to 8 per month), while the standard treatment group shows only modest improvement (2 to 4). The CM group's accelerating early trajectory is consistent with the escalating voucher system, which increases incentive value for consecutive negative samples. This pattern is consistent with the strong evidence base for contingency management in substance use disorders, demonstrating that systematic reinforcement of abstinence produces superior outcomes to standard treatment alone.

questions.stem: Categorize each procedure according to whether it is based primarily on classical conditioning or operant conditioning principles.

items.text: Systematic desensitization (Wolpe)
Token economy
Aversion therapy with chemical agents
Differential reinforcement of other behavior (DRO)
Shaping through successive approximations
Biofeedback for tension headaches
Flooding / implosive therapy
Contingency management with vouchers

questions.explanation: Classical conditioning-based: systematic desensitization (counterconditioning), aversion therapy (pairing stimuli), flooding/implosive therapy (extinction of conditioned fear). Operant conditioning-based: token economy (secondary reinforcement), DRO (reinforcing absence of behavior), shaping (reinforcing approximations), contingency management (reinforcement contingencies). Biofeedback combines both: classical conditioning-based relaxation with operant learning (the feedback signal serves as reinforcement for physiological control).

questions.stem: Categorize each negative punishment and positive punishment procedure according to its correct type.

items.text: Time-out from positive reinforcement
Overcorrection (restitutional and positive practice)
Response cost (losing earned tokens for rule violations)
Taking aspirin to relieve a headache, increasing aspirin-taking
A child having a toy removed after aggressive behavior
Requiring a student to write an essay on proper behavior after disrupting class

questions.explanation: Negative punishment (removing something desirable to decrease behavior): time-out, response cost, toy removal. Positive punishment (adding something aversive to decrease behavior): overcorrection, writing an essay requirement. Negative reinforcement (removing something aversive to increase behavior): aspirin relieving headache increases aspirin-taking. The key distinction: 'positive' = adding, 'negative' = removing; reinforcement increases behavior, punishment decreases it.
